content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <rdf:RDF  xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"  xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/"  xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"  xmlns:prism="http://prismstandard.org/namespaces/1.2/basic/">   <channel rdf:about="http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept">     <title>Concept</title>   <link>http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept</link>            <description>The Journal of Contemporary Community Education Practice Theory. The Concept Journal offers a lively independent forum for critical debate and exchange of ideas in contemporary Community Education. Community Education is seen in the broadest sense to include community work, adult education and youth work and takes place in a range of settings and agencies. We see the concept of community education as dynamic and diverse and do not seek to reflect a fixed view.</description>              <dc:language>en-US</dc:language>      <prism:publicationName>Concept</prism:publicationName>               <prism:issn>1359 1983</prism:issn>         <prism:copyright><p>Authors who publish with this journal agree to the following terms:</p><p>a. Authors retain copyright and grant the journal right of first publication with the work simultaneously licensed under an Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 2.5 UK: Scotland license that allows others to share the work with an acknowledgement of the work's authorship and initial publication in this journal.</p><p>More information on Creative Commons here: <a href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/2.5/scotland/">http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/2.5/scotland/</a></p><p>b. Authors are able to enter into separate, additional contractual arrangements for the non-exclusive distribution of the journal's published version of the work (e.g., post it to an institutional repository or publish it in a book), with an acknowledgement of its initial publication in this journal.</p><p>c. Authors are permitted and encouraged to post their work online (e.g., in institutional repositories or on their website) prior to and during the submission process, as it can lead to productive exchanges, as well as earlier and greater citation of published work (See <a href="http://opcit.eprints.org/oacitation-biblio.html" target="_new">The Effect of Open Access</a>).</p></prism:copyright> </rdf:Seq>   </items>  </channel>     <item rdf:about="http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/277">        <title>Concept Journal</title>    <link>http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/277</link>            <description>Concept Journal Full Issue</description>            <dc:creator>Full Issue</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-25</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-25</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>5</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/271">        <title>New Managerialism: The Impact on Education</title>    <link>http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/271</link>            <description>With the rise of the\ufffd\ufffdneo-liberalism as a system of values, there is an increasing attempt to off-load the cost of education, health care and public services generally, on to the individual. Allied to this, there is a growing movement to privatise those areas of public services that could be run for profit, including higher education.<p>New managerialism represents the organisational arm of neoliberalism. It is the mode of governance designed to realize the neoliberal project through the institutionalising of market principles in the governance of organizations. While Taylorism and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdscientific management have been employed extensively to for-profit businesses for many decades, what makes new managerialism \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnew\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd is the deployment of managerialist principles in both public sector bodies (Lynch, Grummell and Devine, 2012), and, increasingly, in non-governmental organisations (McCrea, 2014).</p><div><div><p>\ufffd\ufffd</p></div></div></description>            <dc:creator>Kathleen Lynch</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-24</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-24</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>5</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/272">        <title>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdRight, I can do this now\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. Community Based Adult Learning, Health and Well-being</title>    <link>http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/272</link>            <description><p><em>This article explores the experiences of participants in community based adult learning (CBAL) in relation to health and well-being. It draws on data from a small-scale life history study undertaken with 10 adult learners in two local authority areas in Scotland. The article concludes that, for some learners, participation in CBAL had contributed to a sense of well-being and was seen by them as supporting their capacity to cope with ill-health.\ufffd\ufffd In addition, it is suggested that community based adult learning can play a role in the recovery from mental ill-health and depression.\ufffd\ufffd </em></p></description>            <dc:creator>Janis McIntyre</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-24</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-24</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>5</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/273">        <title>Imagining a different future</title>    <link>http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/273</link>            <description><p><em>Most providers engage in evaluation but, often, there is little opportunity to record in any depth the experience of returning to learning and the difference it has made to learners. For that reason, the Edinburgh Adult Education Research Group undertook 10 life-story interviews with students to examine in-depth the impact adult learning had on their lives</em></p></description>            <dc:creator>Lorrane Borwick</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Elizabeth Bryan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jim Crowther</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>James Gilfillan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Birgit Harris</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-24</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-24</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>5</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/275">        <title>Foucault\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Concept of Counter-Conduct and the Politics of Anti-Austerity Protest in Ireland</title>    <link>http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/275</link>            <description>Since the announcement of the Irish recession in 2008, there has been much media and popular speculation regarding the apparent failure of the Irish people to collectively resist austerity.\ufffd\ufffd The socialisation of private banking debt and successive fiscal \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdadjustments\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, which have seen huge reductions in public spending, disproportionately impacting on the Irish community and voluntary sector (Harvey, 2012), have not generated sustained opposition from civil society.\ufffd\ufffd Apocryphal stories of Greek protesters chanting \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdwe are not like Ireland\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd or the current Irish Minister for Finance Michael Noonan\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds threats to print t-shirts with the slogan \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWe\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre not Greece\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, belie a more complex reality.\ufffd\ufffd Evidently, as Laurence Cox (2012) has observed in this journal \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdresponses from working class communities and social movements\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd have been \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdminimal\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd In the absence of a widely-shared and enacted anti-austerity politics, there have been regular manifestations of localised or sectoralised opposition to welfare retrenchment, service withdrawal, and the introduction of new levies or charges (Allen, 2012). It is important to note, however, that their achievements to date have been variable.</description>            <dc:creator>Rosie Meade</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-24</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-24</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>5</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/276">        <title>Learning with Adults: The Role of Practice in the Formation of Adults</title>    <link>http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/276</link>            <description><p>Practice\ufffd\ufffd has for a long time been an important feature of adult learning and the debates centering around this field. It is\ufffd\ufffd common to attach importance to this aspect of an adult\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds learning and life trajectory in evaluations of university programmes focusing specifically on adults. The emphasis here is on engaging the adults\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd life experiences. This is based on the belief, following Freire, that the starting points of effective learning are the learners\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd concrete existential situations. With this view in mind, different sites of practice (family, work, communal etc.)\ufffd\ufffd are regarded as important \ufffd\ufffdsites of learning.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Peter Mayo</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-25</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-25</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>5</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/274">        <title>Thomas Piketty, Capital in the Twenty First Century</title>    <link>http://concept.lib.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Concept/article/view/274</link>            <description>Capital in the Twenty First Century</description>            <dc:creator>Nigel Hewlett</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-24</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-24</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>5</prism:volume>   </item>  </rdf:RDF>
